title: Generators call for notice as smelters teeter on the brink
text:
Unions warned the smelter was "too big to fail" and its exit would devastate the economy in western Victoria, but Allan Gray managing director Simon Mawhinney said Portland should not be kept alive for social reasons alone.

''I don't have the specific details on its current profitability, but if Portland is unprofitable and is without a reasonable pathway to profitability, there is no reason it should be kept open and any financial support would be better spent on helping the affected employees,'' said Mr Mawhinney, whose fund controls close to 2 per cent of the smelter through its shareholding in Alumina Limited.

Rio Tinto operates aluminium smelters near Gladstone in Queensland, Newcastle in NSW and Bell Bay in Tasmania, and warned in August that those smelters were "on thin ice".

EnergyAustralia said the closure of an aluminium smelter would have "implications" for the energy market.

''We’ve been clear that Australia’s shrinking capacity to generate reliable energy has been a major cause of rising household power prices, and that there is a fine balance between market supply and demand, particularly in Victoria," EnergyAustralia markets executive Ross Edwards said.

"By taking any large form of demand out of the system there would naturally be implications for all forms of generation.

"Australia’s transition to a cleaner energy system should be orderly and with sufficient notice given, as to ensure a smooth transition."

Advertisement

Energy experts were divided over whether the exit of Portland, which is responsible for about 10 per cent of Victoria's power demand, could hasten the closure of EnergyAustralia's Yallourn coal generator, widely seen as the most vulnerable, as it is the oldest and least flexible of the remaining brown coal plants.

While the closure of the smelter would loosen the tight supply-demand balance, taking stress off Yallourn, some argue the plant would be more exposed to fluctuating power prices through the day, while wholesale prices overall would be lower.

Mr Taylor challenged Victoria's Labor government to ensure the state's coal-fired power fleet was not forced out of business early.

"The Andrews government needs to prioritise the affordability and reliability of their grid, and ensure their thermal generators stay in the market, running at full tilt, to ensure the viability of Victorian industry into the future," he said.

AGL Energy, the existing supplier of the 500 MW electricity contract for the smelter via the Loy Yang power station in the Latrobe Valley, signalled it was expecting the plant to continue to operate.

"We would like to be considered as a potential supplier for Alcoa, post the expiration of their existing contract," an AGL spokeswoman said.

The federal government's $30 million grant for Portland is conditional on the smelter operating until at least the end of June 2021, with part of the money to be refunded by the owners if it closes before that, under a sliding scale.

Advertisement

About $15 million would need to be repaid to the government if the smelter shut in fiscal 2020, while $7.5 million would have to be repaid if the plant closed in the year to June 30, 2021.

But the Morrison government wouldn't comment on whether it would consider extending federal subsidies to Portland to keep the plant in operation.

"Alcoa has not identified any specific operations that are likely to be affected by its review, so it’s premature to speculate about the future of its Portland smelter," Minister for Industry, Science and Technology Karen Andrews said.

The Victorian government said it was a matter for Alcoa.

Ominously for Portland, Alcoa said reducing its carbon footprint was one of the key goals of the review.

''After the portfolio transformation, the company expects to be the lowest emitter of carbon dioxide among all global aluminum companies, per tonne of emissions in both smelting and refining, and aims to move its aluminum portfolio to a first quartile cost position,'' the company said in a statement.

''In addition, Alcoa anticipates that up to 85 per cent of its smelting portfolio will be powered by renewable energy, building upon the company’s existing sustainability profile.''

AMWU organiser Tony Hynds said state and federal governments should send a delegation to meet with Alcoa in the US and strike a deal to secure the smelter's future, while Australian Workers' Union branch secretary Ben Davis said Portland's fate was not sealed yet.

"If Victoria's biggest industrial user of electricity was to close that does not mean cheaper power prices. We have lost too much of our traditional manufacturing, we can't just stand by and let Alcoa and Portland sail into the night quietly, and we won't," he said.

"As an employer they are too big to fail for the region.''
description: Coal-fired generators have called for "sufficient notice'' before an aluminium smelter is allowed to exit the National Electricity Market.
